title: 112_s372
content:
The Act titled "Cybersecurity and Internet Safety Standards Act" defines terms like computers, providers, and Secretary. Congress acknowledges the profound impact of the Internet on daily life in the United States, but also recognizes the risks posed by computers being exploited by malicious actors. Users are often unaware that their computers may be compromised, leading to threats to computer networks, critical infrastructure, and key resources in the country. Cybersecurity and Internet safety are crucial issues due to the threat of malicious actors compromising computer networks and critical infrastructure. Collaboration between the Government and private sector is necessary to establish cybersecurity standards to prevent such attacks. SEC. 4. COST-BENEFIT ANALYSIS. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant authorities, must analyze the costs and benefits of implementing cybersecurity standards for computer users to prevent malicious activities. Factors to consider include impacts on homeland security, the economy, innovation, liberty, and privacy. The Secretary must analyze the costs and benefits of implementing cybersecurity standards for computer users, considering impacts on homeland security, the economy, innovation, liberty, privacy, and any legal impediments to implementation. SEC. 5. CONSULTATION.

The Secretary will consult with various government agencies, stakeholders, and experts in the academic community to analyze cybersecurity standards for computer networks, critical infrastructure, and key resources.

SEC. 6. REPORT. The Secretary will submit a final report to Congress within 1 year of this Act, including recommendations for cybersecurity standards to prevent malicious actors from compromising computer networks and critical infrastructure. The appropriate committees of Congress include the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation, the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, and the Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate. The appropriate committees of Congress for cybersecurity standards recommendations include the Committee on Energy and Commerce, Homeland Security, Judiciary, and Oversight and Government Reform in the House of Representatives.
